Button special

Floating button

These sample buttons below have their position properties overriden. The original floating button is like the one at the right of the screen.

Just add .is-floating class to a standard button.

Forms

Text

Labels should have the class .o-label or .o-label--inline for labels to be placed inline with the input.

A description span could be added below the input with <span class="o-input__description">Description text</span>.

Textarea

UI Library adds some functionality to textarea fields.
1. Autoheight adaptation depending on the content.
2. Text counter using the textarea property data-maxchars="200".

[custom] push-stretch

"In a village of La Mancha, the name of which I have no desire to call to mind..."

"... there lived not long since one of those gentlemen that keep a lance in the lance-rack, an old buckler, a lean hack, and a greyhound for coursing.

An olla of rather more beef than mutton, a salad on most nights, scraps on Saturdays, lentils on Fridays, and a pigeon or so extra on Sundays, made away with three-quarters of his income. The rest of it went in a doublet of fine cloth and velvet breeches and shoes to match for holidays, while on week-days he made a brave figure in his best homespun.

He had in his house a housekeeper past forty, a niece under twenty, and a lad for the field and market-place, who used to saddle the hack as well as handle the bill-hook.

The age of this gentleman of ours was bordering on fifty; he was of a hardy habit, spare, gaunt-featured, a very early riser and a great sportsman."

"They will have it his surname was Quixada or Quesada (for here there is some difference of opinion among the authors who write on the subject), although from reasonable conjectures it seems plain that he was called Quexana.

This, however, is of but little importance to our tale; it will be enough not to stray a hair's breadth from the truth in the telling of it."

Image Classes

Responsive images

Images can be made responsive-friendly via the addition of the .h-img-responsive class. This applies max-width: 100%;, height: auto; and display: block; to the image so that it scales nicely to the parent element.

Example

Retina images

Specify two image paths and the @1x image dimensions, and it will provide an @2x media query. If you have many images to serve, consider writing your retina image CSS manually in a single media query.

Example

Usage:

.test-image__retina {
@include img-retina("images/demo/1x.png", "images/demo/2x.png", 200px, 200px);
}

Panels

Header panel

Panel header with a longer than normal title

Panel child

The path of the righteous man is beset on all sides by the iniquities of the selfish and the tyranny of evil men. Blessed is he who, in the name of charity and good will, shepherds the weak through the valley of darkness, for he is truly his brother's keeper and the finder of lost children. And I will strike down upon thee with great vengeance and furious anger those who would attempt to poison and destroy My brothers. And you will know My name is the Lord when I lay My vengeance upon thee.

Normal panel

The path of the righteous man is beset on all sides by the iniquities of the selfish and the tyranny of evil men. Blessed is he who, in the name of charity and good will, shepherds the weak through the valley of darkness, for he is truly his brother's keeper and the finder of lost children. And I will strike down upon thee with great vengeance and furious anger those who would attempt to poison and destroy My brothers. And you will know My name is the Lord when I lay My vengeance upon thee.

Paragraphs

Your bones don't break, mine do. That's clear. Your cells react to bacteria and viruses differently than mine. You don't get sick, I do. That's also clear. But for some reason, you and I react the exact same way to water. We swallow it too fast, we choke. We get some in our lungs, we drown. However unreal it may seem, we are connected, you and I. We're on the same curve, just on opposite ends.

Do you see any Teletubbies in here? Do you see a slender plastic tag clipped to my shirt with my name printed on it? Do you see a little Asian child with a blank expression on his face sitting outside on a mechanical helicopter that shakes when you put quarters in it? No? Well, that's what you see at a toy store. And you must think you're in a toy store, because you're here shopping for an infant named Jeb.

This is an abbrevation
This is small text

Visibility Classes

Visibility classes let you show or hide elements based on screen size or device orientation. You can also use visibility classes to control which elements users see depending on their browsing environment.

Visibility classes use !important to ensure they aren't overriden by more specific selectors. This is the only component in the framework that uses !important.

Generic Hide Classes

.l-hide-all and .l-show-all classes are breakpoint independent. You can use them wherever you need.

Hide by Screen Size

.l-hide-tiny, .l-hide-small, .l-hide-medium, .l-hide-large, .l-hide-xlarge classes are breakpoint aware. They will hide an element for a specific screen size.

Example

This block will be hidden on tiny screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on small screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on medium screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on large screen sizes.

This block will be hidden on xlarge screen sizes.

Show by Screen Size

.l-show-tiny, .l-show-small, .l-show-medium, .l-show-large, .l-show-xlarge classes are breakpoint aware. They will show an element for a specific screen size.

Example

The screen SIZE is:

TINY

SMALL

MEDIUM

LARGE

XLARGE

Orientation Detection

.h-show-for-landscape, .h-show-for-portrait classes are breakpoint aware. They will show an element for a specific screen orientation.

Example

The screen ORIENTATION is:

LANDSCAPE

PORTRAIT

Accessibility

Adding one of the .h-hide-xxx classes to an element will prevent screen readers from reading it. However, there are techniques to hide content while still making it readable by screen readers. Class .show-for-sr will be visually hidden but still allowing assistive technology to read it.

Example

Press TAB to see how a hidden block is shown when it gets focused.

YOU HAVE AN SCREEN READER

THIS IS HIDDEN UNTIL FOCUS

Hide for Screen Readers Only

To hide text from assistive technology, while still keeping it visible, add the attribute aria-hidden="true". This doesn't affect how the element looks, but screen readers will skip over it.

This text can be seen, but won't be read by a screen reader.
